prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

response.output:
Here is the revised paragraph with copy-editing changes:

Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Key changes:
- Corrected spelling of "karry" to "carry"
- Corrected spelling of "ekspression" to "expression" 
- Changed "studies has" to "studies have" for subject-verb agreement
- Corrected spelling of "improoved" to "improved"

Has roughly the same length as input

prompt.raw:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
Context: Genes function in interconnected networks that are specific to different biological contexts, and variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and impact disease-relevant processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. 

Content: To understand how genes influence complex traits, it is crucial to mechanistically decipher gene expression regulation across various cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which could lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have characterized different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and described genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. 

Conclusion: However, further research is needed to comprehensively elucidate the complex interplay between genetic variation, gene expression, and disease etiology to facilitate the development of targeted therapies.

The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output:
Context: Genes function in complex, context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and, consequently, influence disease-relevant pathways [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].

Content: To understand how genes contribute to complex traits, it is crucial to elucidate the mechanisms of expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which can lead to the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have characterized various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and investigated genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The integration of functional genomics and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: However, further research is needed to comprehensively understand how genetic variations influence gene expression patterns and, ultimately, contribute to the development of complex diseases and traits.

Integrating functional genomics and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, further research is needed to comprehensively map the regulatory landscape and its impact on disease pathogenesis across diverse cell types and tissues.

Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) provide an effective approach to identify biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data and offering mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Changes made:
1. Removed the first "However" to improve flow and clarity.
2. Moved the explanation of TWAS before mentioning its limitations for better context.
3. Expanded the GWAS acronym.
4. Separated the applications of TWAS (disease etiology, risk prediction, and drug repurposing) into a new sentence for clarity.
5. Moved the limitation of TWAS to the end of the paragraph for a more logical flow.

The availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has enabled the development of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) to identify biological processes underlying complex traits and diseases. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. While TWAS has been highly successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], it operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

response.output: Context: Integrating gene expression data across tissues with genetic variants has proven effective in elucidating the biological processes underlying complex diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Content: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is one such approach that leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic insights into genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Conclusion: However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level, highlighting the need for novel approaches that can integrate gene expression and genetic data to uncover the intricate relationships between genes and their role in disease pathogenesis.

Here is the revised paragraph with copy-editing changes:

Genes work together in context-specific networks to carry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Key changes:
- Corrected spelling of "karry" to "carry"
- Corrected spelling of "ekspression" to "expression" 
- Changed "studies has" to "studies have" for subject-verb agreement
- Corrected spelling of "improoved" to "improved"

Context: Genes function in interconnected networks that are specific to different biological contexts, and variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and impact disease-relevant processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].

Integrating functional genomics and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. 

Conclusion: However, further research is needed to comprehensively elucidate the complex interplay between genetic variation, gene expression, and disease etiology to facilitate the development of targeted therapies.

Context: Genes function in complex, context-specific networks to carry out various biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and, consequently, influence disease-relevant pathways [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6].

Content: To understand how genes contribute to complex traits, it is crucial to elucidate the mechanisms of expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which can lead to the development of improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have characterized various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] and investigated genetic effects on gene expression across tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. The integration of functional genomics and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Conclusion: However, further research is needed to comprehensively understand how genetic variations influence gene expression patterns and, ultimately, contribute to the development of complex diseases and traits.

Integrating functional genomics data with genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improved the identification of transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, often lead to tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. Conclusion: However, further research is needed to elucidate the complex interplay between genetic variations, gene expression, and disease etiology to develop more targeted therapeutic interventions.

Here is the revised paragraph:

Gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] enables the identification of biological processes through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Context: Integrating gene expression data across tissues with genetic variants has proven to be a powerful approach for elucidating the biological processes underlying human diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. 

Content: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) to mechanistically interpret genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. 

Conclusion: However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which fails to capture the more complex interactions that occur at the network level, leaving a critical gap in our understanding of the systems-level mechanisms underlying disease pathogenesis.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

keywords = [

  "Introduction:",
  "Keywords:",
  "References:",
]

  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

vars: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

---
Here is the revised paragraph:

Gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] enables the identification of biological processes through transcription-wide association studies (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Changes made:
1. Restructured the first sentence for clarity and conciseness.
2. Spelled out the acronym "GWAS" at first mention.
3. Split the second sentence into two for better readability.
4. Clarified the use of polygenic scores in disease-risk prediction.
5. Replaced "works" with "operates" for more precise language.

outputs.text: Context: Gene expression data across multiple tissues has become increasingly available in recent years [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Conclusion: However, TWAS focuses on individual genes, which may not capture the more complex interactions occurring at the network level, highlighting the need for further research into gene-gene interactions and their role in disease etiology.

Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful approach to elucidate the biological processes underlying genetic associations by integrating gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. 

Content: TWAS leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to test whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Conclusion: However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level, leaving a gap in our understanding of how gene-gene interactions contribute to disease etiology and the identification of potential therapeutic targets.

Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful approach to elucidate the regulatory mechanisms underlying the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Content: By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS has successfully unraveled disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], facilitated disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and guided drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Conclusion: However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may not fully capture the complex interactions and network-level effects that contribute to disease pathogenesis and therapeutic responses, highlighting the need for complementary approaches that extend beyond single-gene associations.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful approach to elucidate the role of gene regulatory mechanisms in mediating the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS has successfully unraveled disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], facilitated disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and aided in drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, despite its effectiveness in identifying biological processes at the individual gene level, TWAS falls short in capturing the more complex interactions that occur at the network level, leaving a gap in our understanding of the intricate interplay between genetic variants, gene expression, and disease pathogenesis.

Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Context: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful approach to elucidate the regulatory mechanisms underlying the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Content: By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776], TWAS has successfully unraveled disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], facilitated disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and enabled drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Conclusion: However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which limits its ability to capture more complex interactions at the network level, highlighting the need for novel approaches that can uncover the intricate relationships between genes and their collective impact on disease pathogenesis.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful approach to elucidate the role of gene regulatory mechanisms in mediating the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS has not only advanced our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but has also shown promise in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, as TWAS operates at the individual gene level, it fails to capture the more complex interactions that occur at the network level, potentially limiting its ability to provide a comprehensive understanding of the biological processes underlying disease pathogenesis.

Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are an effective approach for identifying biological processes associated with complex traits and diseases by integrating gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] with expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. TWAS tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

1. Rearranged the sentences to improve the logical flow of the paragraph.
2. Added a brief explanation of TWAS at the beginning of the paragraph.
3. Removed redundant information about TWAS relying on testing gene regulatory mechanisms.
4. Clarified that polygenic scores are used for disease-risk prediction.
5. Moved the limitation of TWAS to the end of the paragraph to emphasize the gap in current approaches.

Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) are an effective approach to identify biological processes associated with human diseases by integrating gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] with expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

The main changes are:

1. Rearranged the sentences to improve the logical flow of the paragraph.
2. Removed redundant information about TWAS relying on testing gene regulatory mechanisms, as this was already mentioned in the previous sentence.
3. Grouped the applications of TWAS (understanding disease etiology, disease-risk prediction, and drug repurposing) into a single sentence for better readability.
4. Moved the limitation of TWAS to the end of the paragraph to emphasize the need for more complex network-level approaches.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Context: Gene expression data across multiple tissues has become increasingly available in recent years [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Content: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is an effective approach that integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Conclusion: However, TWAS works at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level, highlighting a gap in our understanding of the role of gene regulatory networks in disease etiology and drug mechanisms.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has enabled the development of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) to elucidate the biological processes underlying complex diseases. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic insights into genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which fails to capture more complex interactions at the network level, leaving a gap in our understanding of the intricate relationships between genes and their collective influence on disease pathogenesis.

---
Here is the revised paragraph:

Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) provide an effective approach to identify biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data and offering mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction using polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Changes made:
1. Removed the first "However" to improve flow and clarity.
2. Moved the explanation of TWAS before mentioning its limitations for better context.
3. Expanded the GWAS acronym.
4. Separated the applications of TWAS (disease etiology, risk prediction, and drug repurposing) into a new sentence for clarity.
5. Moved the limitation of TWAS to the end of the paragraph for a more logical flow.

You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Context: Integrating gene expression data across tissues with genetic variants has proven effective in elucidating the biological processes underlying complex diseases [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. Content: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS) is one such approach that leverages expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic insights into genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Conclusion: However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level, highlighting the need for novel approaches that can integrate gene expression and genetic data to uncover the intricate relationships between genes and their role in disease pathogenesis.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input

outputs.text: Gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9] has enabled the development of transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) to identify biological processes underlying complex traits and diseases. TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings by testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], as well as in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level, highlighting the need for novel methods that can integrate gene expression data with network-level information to further elucidate the biological mechanisms underlying complex traits and diseases.

    "value": description,

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"

input = context["vars"]["content"]

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: file://./inputs/title.txt
vars.keywords: file://./inputs/keywords.txt
vars.content: file://./inputs/has_references_to_articles.md

assert.value:
description = "Keeps most references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])
res = (count / len(references) > 0.50)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Does not make up references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

import re

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in references])
res = (n_fake_refs == 0)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}
